{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient's rectovaginal swab culture grew bacitracin-resistant colonies of gram-positive cocci with surrounding areas of clear hemolysis. This is indicative of Group B Streptococcus (GBS) infection. GBS is a common cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis. The primary strategy to prevent neonatal GBS disease is through intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis. The antibiotic of choice is penicillin, but for those allergic to penicillin, ampicillin can be used. Breastfeeding does not affect GBS transmission, amniocentesis is not indicated for GBS, and intravenous immune globulin postpartum is not a standard treatment for GBS.", "answer_choice": "B. Administer ampicillin intrapartum"}
